title: 112_s3527
content: The "Student Visa Integrity Act" defines SEVIS as the Student and Exchange Visitor Information System and SEVP as the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. The Act also includes increased criminal penalties. The "Student Visa Integrity Act" amends Chapter 75 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section that imposes criminal penalties for filing a certification petition under false pretenses with the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. Offenders who misrepresent themselves as officials of an educational institution face fines, imprisonment for 2 to 15 years, or both. The term 'false pretenses' includes making materially false statements. The "Student Visa Integrity Act" imposes criminal penalties for filing false certification petitions with the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. Offenders face fines, imprisonment for 2 to 15 years, or both for making materially false statements. The "Student Visa Integrity Act" imposes penalties for filing false certification petitions with the Student and Exchange Visitor Program. The United States Sentencing Commission will amend sentencing guidelines for violations of this act. Additionally, an accreditation requirement is established. Section 101(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change the requirements for student visas, including the institutions where they can be obtained and the authority responsible for them. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to update requirements for student visas, specifying accredited institutions for eligibility. SEC. 5. OTHER REQUIREMENTS FOR ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS. Section 214(m) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require accreditation of academic institutions for certain visa purposes, with the option for waiver under specific conditions. The Student Visa Integrity Act requires academic institutions seeking accreditation to be in compliance with specific requirements and to be a candidate for accreditation by an approved agency for at least 1 year. SEC. 6. STUDENT START DATE FOR PROGRAM TO COLLECT INFORMATION RELATING TO FOREIGN STUDENTS AND OTHER EXCHANGE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS. The Student Visa Integrity Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to set a start date for the program at approved educational institutions. Technical amendments replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security" in the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996. The Student Visa Integrity Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to make technical amendments in the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, replacing references to the "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security". The Student Visa Integrity Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to make technical amendments in the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, replacing references to the "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security". Additionally, the act addresses visa fraud in Section 7. The Student Visa Integrity Act amends the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to immediately withdraw SEVP certification if there is reasonable suspicion of fraud by an owner or designated official at an approved educational institution. The Student Visa Integrity Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to withdraw SEVP certification immediately if there is suspicion of fraud by an owner or official at an approved educational institution. If indicted for fraud, certification will be withdrawn and access to SEVIS terminated during the criminal prosecution. The Student Visa Integrity Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to withdraw SEVP certification immediately if there is suspicion of fraud by an owner or official at an approved educational institution. If indicted for fraud, certification will be withdrawn and access to SEVIS terminated during the criminal prosecution. Additionally, a designated school official or owner convicted of fraud related to the Student and Exchange Visitor Program will be permanently disqualified from filing future petitions and holding any ownership or management roles in US educational institutions enrolling nonimmigrant alien students. The Student Visa Integrity Act allows immediate withdrawal of SEVP certification if fraud is suspected by an owner or official at an approved educational institution. Certification will be revoked if indicted for fraud, with access to SEVIS terminated during criminal prosecution. Conviction of fraud related to the Student and Exchange Visitor Program results in permanent disqualification from filing future petitions or holding management roles in US educational institutions enrolling nonimmigrant alien students. SEC. 8. BACKGROUND CHECKS AND USE OF E-VERIFY. SEC. 8. BACKGROUND CHECKS AND USE OF E-VERIFY. Amends Section 641(d) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 to include a background check requirement for designated school officials accessing SEVIS. Individual must be a U.S. national or lawful permanent resident with a recent 3-year background check by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The individual's criminal and sex offender history, as well as their immigration status verified by the school through the E-Verify Program. The individual must not have any convictions related to immigration or national security, and must have completed an online training course on SEVP. The individual must complete an online training course on SEVP and SEVIS developed by the Secretary to serve as an interim designated school official during the background check period. If the background check is not successful, the Secretary will review each Form I-20 issued. The Secretary will review each Form I-20 issued by the interim designated school official and collect a fee for background checks conducted. The fee amount will be equal to the average cost incurred by the Secretary for conducting such checks. The amendment will take effect one year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 9. REVOCATION OF AUTHORITY TO ISSUE FORM I-20. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Homeland Security will prohibit uncertified flight schools from accessing SEVIS or issuing Form I-20 to alien students. Similarly, schools not licensed by a state will be prohibited from accessing SEVIS or issuing Form I-20 within 180 days. Aliens seeking student visas must attend schools licensed or authorized to offer post-secondary credentials by a State. The Secretary may waive this requirement for religious-affiliated, elementary, or secondary schools. SEC. 10. REVOCATION OF ACCREDITATION. When an accrediting agency revokes accreditation from an institution, they must notify the Secretary of Homeland Security, who will then remove the school from SEVP and block access to SEVIS. SEC. 11. REPORT ON RISK ASSESSMENT. SEC. 11. REPORT ON RISK ASSESSMENT. Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must provide a report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees outlining the risk assessment strategy for identifying and addressing schools and officials aiding in visa violations. Within 180 days of enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees detailing the risk assessment process for allocating resources in the Student and Exchange Visitor Program (SEVP), ensuring school eligibility, addressing missing school case files, monitoring school accreditation status, and certifying flight schools. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report on the risk assessment process for resource allocation in the SEVP, school eligibility, missing case files, school accreditation monitoring, and certifying flight schools. Additionally, procedures for coordination among SEVP, Counterterrorism Unit, and ICE field offices, as well as criteria for referring potentially criminal cases to the intelligence community, have been established. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to complete the deployment of SEVIS II within 2 years of the enactment of the Act.
